messageBody:
>-- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> peter_r_guinness scripsit:
>
> > FORCE = 33 Awe + 25 Roe
> > NORTH = 33 Awe + 25 Roe
>
> I'm now thinking that the small number of NORTH words should be
written
> Owe + Roe rather than Awe + Roe, to accommodate people who do make
the
> distinction: speakers in Scotland, Ireland, the Caribbean, and parts
of
> the U.S.
>

Personally I don't think that we should make the distinction because
the greater majority don't and that the spelt difference in
pronunciation would cause confusion and seem odd to them.
However, if instead we designed a symbol that looked similar to 'Awe'
but sounds as a NORTH set vowel than I would support making it
optional since it wouldn't interfere much with the readability of a
text for the bulk of readers. (eg: such as an 'Awe' with a short mid-
letter dash through it--although this breaks Read's goal of no-pen-
lifts when writing a letter)

I could create a special key-mapping just for my project that maps a
letter for the NORTH set distinction to 'Awe' so that if someone
latter wants to use the distinction that can simply find/replace that
letter with the letter that maps to 'Owe'. Although, unfortunately
I'm not at all familiar with the distinction so don't really know
which words are NORTH or FORCE (besides applying the rules John gave).

> > I would also like to know what people think about the distinction
> > between 'Way' (18) and 'Why' (20) - should they be merged,
optional
> > distinction or kept distinct?
>

For me I support making the distinction optional with 'Why' being
replaced with 'Way' for those who don't choose to keep the distincion.
Since the graphemes for 'Way' and 'Why' are very similar it doesn't
cause much difficulty to the majority (who don't make the distinction)
to read a text that does make the distinction and uses 'Why'. Also
since the functional loading is very low and the phonemes sound
similar not much confusion is caused to people who do make the
distinction who read a text that doesn't use 'Why'.
